Building on the foundational skills obtained in the Bachelor's programme, the Master of Arts (M.A.) in Art History at our university provides a comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the discipline. The curriculum covers diverse methodological approaches, technical skills, and a broad spectrum of artistic genres and epochs. For more detailed information, please refer to the study structure chapter. Single Honours MA in Art History with a focus on Curatorial Studies (78 credits) Joint Honours MA in Art History (42 credits) Joint Honours MA (42 credits) with a focus on Curatorial Studies Module package in Art History (36 credits / 18 credits) in combination with a Joint Honours MA in another subject The M.A. in Art History with a specialisation in Curatorial Studies uniquely blends practical experience with theoretical and historical insights into art. This program not only covers the collection, management, and exhibition of artworks but also promotes critical reflection on their historical and theoretical contexts. Over four semesters, students gain essential skills and knowledge through hands-on experiences with original artworks from the Göttingen University Art Collection. Supplementary internships further enrich practical learning, offering work-related experiences beyond the university. Students also receive rigorous training in the historical and theoretical dimensions of art, fostering a scientifically reflective approach to artistic objects. This specialisation is ideal for those with a background in art history, art studies, visual studies, or related disciplines. At Göttingen, art history is taught with an expansive view that covers its entire historical and thematic breadth. Special emphases include the art history of the Middle Ages and early modern period in Italy, 19th-century visual arts, modernity, historical theories of images and art, transcultural connections, and the materiality of knowledge. A unique feature of our institute is the curatorial training offered through our art collection, one of the few university collections in Germany housing treasures from the Middle Ages to the present. Our collection includes approximately 2,500 hand drawings, 15,000 prints, 300 paintings, various sculptures, and a photo and video art collection. Students engage with original artworks from the outset of their studies, gaining hands-on experience that is crucial for professional practice in art history. Regular project seminars and research opportunities are integral parts of the curriculum, allowing students to curate exhibitions and publish their research in high-quality exhibition catalogues. We maintain strong collaborations with renowned institutions such as the Landesmuseum Hannover, HAWK Hildesheim, Herzog-Anton-Ulrich-Museum in Braunschweig, the Museumslandschaft Hessen-Kassel, and the Lower Saxony Department of Monument Preservation. Additionally, students benefit from regular excursions and study-abroad opportunities at European partner universities. Within the university, the Department of Art History works closely with the university collections, the Institute for Digital Humanities, various research institutions on campus, and the Forum Wissen. Particularly close collaborations exist with object-based, historical, and cultural studies subjects. The Master's programme in Art History prepares graduates for diverse career paths, including positions in museums, heritage conservation, academia, galleries, the art trade, tourism, publishing, media, insurance, and cultural management. Graduates with a specialisation in Curatorial Studies are particularly equipped for roles in museums, classical and modern art collections, galleries, auction houses, and the art trade. Moreover, this degree programme qualifies students for academic careers and is a stepping stone for doctoral studies in art history, providing the necessary foundation for pursuing research in universities and non-university research institutions.

What is Computer Science? Computer Science is the discipline centered around the systematic and automated processing of information. It encompasses the study of the structures, characteristics, and descriptions of information processing, as well as the setup, methodologies, and construction principles of computer systems. The field explores general processes in information processing and their applications across various domains. Additionally, it includes the development of contemporary experimental and product-oriented information systems. The broad areas of Computer Science include Theoretical, Practical, Technical, and Applied Computer Science. Student Experience Our students will have the opportunity to explore models and simulations that structure, formalize, and mathematize application areas. They will gain expertise in the engineering facets of software system development with a focus on adaptability and human-computer interaction. The program aims to provide foundational and practical knowledge of Computer Science, equipping students with problem-solving skills and their implementations. Practical Experience A significant emphasis is placed on real-world application. Students can enhance their practical knowledge through internships in industrial enterprises or research institutions, establishing a robust connection between theoretical learning and practical experience. Is Computer Science Right for You? If you are passionate about mathematics and computers and aspire to make an impact in fields like biology, economics, medicine, or the humanities, Computer Science at Göttingen could be your ideal path. A collaborative spirit and teamwork are essential, as these skills are intrinsic to the program and future professional roles. While prior knowledge of English isn't required, it is beneficial for programming and global collaboration. Why Study in Göttingen? Göttingen offers you the unique opportunity to study Applied Computer Science both at the Bachelor's and Master's levels. Our curriculum provides solid foundations in theoretical and mathematical aspects of Computer Science while allowing you to delve into specialized, application-oriented areas. Tailor your learning experience with majors like business informatics, neuroinformatics, bioinformatics, or geoinformatics, allowing you to engage in cutting-edge technologies and innovative research. Specialization Opportunities In Göttingen, you can choose from various specializations such as business informatics, neuroinformatics, bioinformatics, or geoinformatics. These options provide insights into the latest technologies and research-oriented teaching, enabling you to gain a comprehensive understanding of the subject-specific and practical forms of teaching. Explore Diverse Career Paths At the Institute of Computer Science in Göttingen University, you are prepared for innovative and dynamic professional fields. With thorough education in Applied Computer Science, you can contribute to future technologies in medicine, biotechnology, business, geosciences, environmental technology, and ecosystem research. Musicology: Exploring the Art and Science of Music Musicology is an enriching and dynamic field that invites you to explore the profound impact of music on human culture, identity, and society. What is Musicology? Musicology is the scholarly study of music, encompassing its nature, mechanisms, and meanings. Beyond being a mere form of entertainment, music is a powerful lens through which we can gain insights into people's histories, cultures, and interpersonal relationships. It reveals the diverse ways in which communities express, define, and share their identities. At the University of Göttingen's Department of Musicology, we embrace the philosophy that there is not just one type of music, but a multitude. Each musical form is a unique narrative, reflecting a variety of cultural practices and historical contexts. Through music, we communicate, teach, and build our cultural identities. It serves as both a form of artistic expression and a component of social networks, conveying emotions, ideas, and self-understandings. Research Methods in Musicology Our program emphasizes a comprehensive approach to studying music, incorporating both theoretical and practical methodologies. Our toolkit includes: Historical research (evaluation of written, sound, and visual sources) Field research (participant observation of musical practices) Aural analysis and musical text analysis Sound analysis as a mode of knowledge Computer-assisted analysis (e.g., spectral or frequency analysis) Career Opportunities A Bachelor's degree in Musicology from Göttingen prepares you for diverse career paths in cultural management and politics, media and public relations, theater, and library sciences, among other sectors. Furthermore, it provides a solid foundation for pursuing a Master's degree in Musicology or related fields. Recommended Prior Knowledge Prospective students should possess a basic understanding of musical terminology and theory, including knowledge of notation, intervals, keys, and chords. Practical experience in playing instruments or singing, along with a broad appreciation for different musical styles, will be advantageous. Join Us If you are passionate about music and eager to delve into its study from multiple perspectives, we invite you to join the vibrant academic community at Göttingen. Here, your unique perspective as a woman will enhance and enrich our collective understanding of music's role in human life.

Immerse yourself in the rich tapestry of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine culture and ancient history through our stimulating introductory lectures and engaging tutorials. Our program embraces the latest academic trends in cultural anthropology and interdisciplinary research, offering you an integrative and comparative cultural study experience that is both dynamic and hands-on. Our curriculum is designed to provide internal and external practical courses, including excavation and surveying technology, object documentation through drawing and photography, digital image processing, ceramic analysis and restoration, moulding techniques, museology, monument preservation, and archaeological science journalism—each component contributing to valuable career-qualifying perspectives. Assessment in the program typically involves presentations and written assignments, allowing you to develop essential academic skills. You will master scientific research, critical evaluation, and argumentative writing while enhancing your ability to present findings verbally, visually, and in writing. Our institute's extensive national and international networks, including connections through the Erasmus program, ensure that you experience academic mobility and gain global perspectives from the very start of your Bachelor’s studies. In our degree program, Classical Archaeology, which focuses on early antiquity, complements Christian Archaeology/Byzantine Art History, which explores later antiquity. Through common methodological foundations and overlapping content, you will gain insights into various research areas, ranging from political and religious iconography, stylistic analysis, and cultural interactions, to gender, architecture, landscape studies, and liturgy. At Göttingen, you will benefit from access to excellent libraries and our unique 250-year-old collections of ancient artifacts, sculptures, and coins. From early semesters, you will engage directly with these materials, supported by our institute’s restoration workshop and collaborations with museums in Kassel, Hanover, and Frankfurt. Internships and field research projects in Italy, Greece, and Spain provide additional opportunities for practical archaeological experience. Our program prepares you for diverse career paths in youth and adult education, cultural management, tourism, publishing, media, diplomacy, and international organizations. You may also choose to pursue further academic studies in a Master’s program, preparing for a scientific career in museums, conservation, academia, and research institutions. Join our vibrant community at the Archaeological Institute in Göttingen, where a multifaceted study of archaeology fosters unparalleled training and research opportunities. We invite you to shape your future with us, contributing to fields such as ancient sculpture, iconography, architecture, regional historical studies, numismatics, and the reception of antiquity.

What is Computer Science? Computer Science is a dynamic field that systematically and automatically processes information, encompassing the structures, characteristics, and descriptions of information processing as well as the creation, operation, and construction principles of computer systems. This domain explores general methods in information processing and their applications across various fields, including the development of innovative and experimental information processing systems. Theoretical Computer Science Practical Computer Science Technical Computer Sciences Applied Computer Science Throughout the program, students will learn how to structure, formalize, and model application areas using specialized simulations. They will gain proficiency in the engineering aspects of software system development for various applications, with a focus on adaptability and human-computer interaction. The program aims to impart a comprehensive understanding of both theoretical and practical Computer Science. Students will learn methods to solve application issues and implement them in computer-friendly formats, with a strong emphasis on the application of knowledge in real-world contexts. The program highlights the importance of integrating practical experiences, such as internships in industrial or research settings, to augment academic learning with hands-on exposure. Applicants who enjoy working with mathematics and computers, and have interests in fields like biology, economics, medicine, or the humanities, will find Computer Science in Göttingen to be an ideal choice. A passion for collaborative problem-solving and strong teamwork abilities are essential for a successful career in this field. While a good command of English is beneficial, it is not a prerequisite, especially in programming contexts. At Göttingen, students can pursue a Bachelor's or Master's degree in Applied Computer Science, gaining a balanced education in theoretical foundations and advanced topics in core computer science. Specialized majors allow students to tailor their studies to areas such as business informatics, neuroinformatics, bioinformatics, or geoinformatics, providing insights into current technologies and research-oriented teaching methodologies. Possible specializations include, but are not limited to: business informatics, neuroinformatics, bioinformatics, geoinformatics. A degree from the Institute of Computer Science at Göttingen University equips graduates with the skills needed to thrive in innovative professional fields. Graduates can contribute to future technologies across diverse sectors including medicine, biotechnology, business, geosciences, and environmental technology. Software and hardware development Development and adaptation of application systems and networks Counseling and training Research and teaching Choosing an application specialization enhances career prospects by providing an interdisciplinary education, making graduates highly sought after in various innovative fields. By studying Applied Computer Science, students not only gain robust theoretical knowledge but also practical experience, positioning them to excel in a wide range of cutting-edge careers.

What is it all about? The Business Information Systems degree programme is a multidisciplinary course that integrates business administration, informatics, and specialized business informatics. Key areas include information management, system development, and application systems. Coursework covers topics such as application system design, mobile apps, data management, and machine learning. The program offers a diverse range of electives, enabling you to explore various subjects and discover new interests, including modules outside the core subjects of business informatics and economics. We emphasize real-world applications of your knowledge. All modules are designed to connect theory to practice, easing your transition into the IT industry with current content. In the project seminar on system development, you'll work with real business partners on developing software solutions from start to finish. The IT field evolves rapidly, so we prepare you with both cutting-edge content and timeless methodologies, ensuring that you can adapt to new challenges throughout your career. The programme is fully modularised, requiring you to earn 180 credits to graduate. To be successful in this program, you need solid proficiency in English (and German for international students), as well as strong skills in mathematics and information and communication systems (ICS). If you need to improve in any of these areas, we recommend that you do so before beginning the program. Our Faculty of Business and Economics offers a preparatory Mathematics course every winter and summer semester to help you get up to speed. Motivation and a drive to succeed Interest in entrepreneurial or macroeconomic issues Analytical thinking and comfort with mathematical methods Good proficiency in German and at least working knowledge of English Admission to the Bachelor's degree in Business Information Systems is competitive for the first year but open in subsequent years. Applications are accepted for both the summer and winter semesters. Career Perspectives Graduates with a bachelor's degree in Business Information Systems are in high demand in the job market. You can pursue various roles such as computer specialists, system analysts, and IT consultants. Responsibilities in these roles include planning, documenting, and implementing hardware and software solutions, analyzing organizational impacts, and problem-solving. Specific job titles may include system administrator, technical support specialist, software developer, and IT consultant. You may also find opportunities as project managers, project coordinators, or system analysts, particularly in hybrid roles that combine business and IT expertise. Hybrid experts, who understand both business problems and IT solutions, play crucial roles in coordinating between operating departments and IT departments. Graduates often find themselves in positions such as project managers and system analysts in departments focused on data processing, user consulting, and organizational systems. Explore various professional fields through portraits of our alumni.

Bachelor's Degree in Musicology Musicology is the academic exploration of music, delving into its essence, mechanics, and significance to humanity. Our program embraces the pluralistic nature of music, recognizing its various forms and meanings shaped by global cultures and historical shifts. We believe in studying the multifaceted aspects of music, whether as an artistic expression, a societal function, or a medium of communication and identity. The Göttingen Department of Musicology employs diverse research methodologies to foster a deep understanding of music: Historical research - Evaluating written, audio, and visual sources Field research - Engaging in participant observation of musical practices Auditory analysis - Studying musical texts and sounds Sound analysis - Investigating sound as a mode of knowledge Computer-assisted analysis - Utilizing tools like spectral and frequency analysis Completing a Bachelor's degree in Musicology opens doors to a plethora of career opportunities in cultural management, media, public relations, theater, library science, and related fields. Our program offers an in-depth exploration of Greek, Roman, and Byzantine culture and ancient history. Through a blend of lectures and hands-on tutorials, students are equipped with a comprehensive understanding of these fascinating civilizations. The curriculum integrates cultural anthropology and interdisciplinary research, ensuring a well-rounded educational experience. The program is designed to be highly practical, with opportunities for internal and external practica in diverse fields such as excavation technology, surveying, drawing, photographic documentation, digital image processing, ceramic analysis and restoration, moulding techniques, museology, monument preservation, and archaeological journalism. These practical courses prepare students for various career paths and provide them with essential, real-world skills. Assessment is conducted through a combination of presentations and written assignments, which help students develop critical scientific research skills and additional competencies, including targeted information research, evaluation, and argumentation. Students will also hone their ability to present results effectively, both verbally and in writing. The Archaeological Institute's extensive international networks, including the Erasmus program, enable students to gain valuable experience abroad during their studies. This mobility is available from the Bachelor's level, providing a global perspective on archaeological research. The Bachelor's degree program combines Classical Archaeology and Christian Archaeology/Byzantine Art History, leveraging common methodologies and content overlaps to provide a cohesive study experience. Students are exposed to the diverse research interests of faculty members, such as political and religious iconography, stylistic analysis, cultural contacts, gender studies, architecture, and landscape archaeology. Our institute in Göttingen boasts excellent libraries and a 250-year-old collection of ancient artifacts, casts of sculptures, and coins. These resources are integral to the courses, allowing students to engage directly with archaeological materials from the early semesters. The institute's restoration workshop and collaborations with museums in Kassel, Hanover, and Frankfurt offer additional practical training opportunities. Field research projects in Italy, Greece, and Spain further enhance students' hands-on experience. Graduates of our program are well-equipped for careers in youth and adult education, cultural management, tourism, publishing, media, diplomatic institutions, and international organizations. Additionally, they can pursue a Master's degree to prepare for scientific careers in museums, monument conservation, universities, and research institutions. Our multifaceted approach to the study of archaeology in Göttingen cultivates a rich environment for training and research, particularly in ancient sculpture, iconography, architecture, regional historical studies, numismatics, and the reception of antiquity. Join us to embark on a journey through time and culture, and prepare for a fulfilling career in archaeology and related fields.

Our program offers a hands-on approach to understanding and addressing pressing global issues such as climate change, land use transformation, species loss, and biodiversity threats. With a strong foundation in ecosystems analysis and modeling, the curriculum provides advanced training in programming, data analysis, theoretical ecology, and practical conservation management. Students engage in research-based training on the functionality of terrestrial ecosystems from the molecular to the landscape level. This includes laboratory methods and the sustainable management of tropical and international forests. An interdisciplinary management plan is prepared on-site, offering rich, practical experience. Throughout the program, students participate in cutting-edge research within an interdisciplinary and international environment. The Master's program allows students to specialize in one of three fields: Ecosystem Analysis and Modelling, Ecosystem Sciences, or Tropical and International Forestry. Each specialization imparts both scientific knowledge and professional skills necessary for addressing complex environmental challenges. Students will develop competencies in problem-solving, teamwork, project management, and interdisciplinary thinking and working. The study content varies depending on the chosen specialization. In addition to compulsory courses specific to each program, students can select from a range of optional courses totaling 30 credit points, offered by the Faculty of Forestry, other university faculties, and international partner universities. Students will learn methods of ecosystem analysis and modelling to understand the impact of climate change and new ecosystem management practices. Key skills include problem-solving through simulation and statistical modelling, and presenting results using the latest media formats. Core topics include Introduction to Ecological Modelling, Ecosystem Theory, Biodiversity, Macro-ecology, Biogeography, Soil Sciences, Bioclimatology, Conservation, Computational Methods, Individual and Agent-Based Modelling, Advanced Statistical Data Analysis with R, Functional-Structural Simulation Modelling, and Spatial Modelling. This specialization focuses on the essential functions and services provided by terrestrial ecosystems. Students will acquire critical thinking skills, modern field and laboratory methods, and thorough quantitative training. The program covers a broad range of subjects within the Faculty of Forest Sciences and Forest Ecology. Compulsory topics include Biodiversity and Community Ecology, Ecosystem Analytics, Molecular Ecology and Genetics, Applied Ecology, Soil Sciences and Climatology, and Data Handling and Analysis using R. Aimed at ecological and economic management of tropical forests, this course covers forest utilization and related policies. Students will learn to analyze and monitor ecological consequences, and design silvicultural systems considering both economic and long-term impacts. In the third semester, participants collaborate on the Students' Project, traveling to a host country for field research after preparatory work in Göttingen. Regions of research in recent years include Uganda, Laos, and Myanmar. Core topics include Introduction to Tropical Forest Ecology and Silviculture, International Forest Policy and Economics, Monitoring Forest Resources, Forest Utilization and Wood Processing, Soil Science, Bioclimatology, Resource Analysis, Different Silvicultural Systems, Biometrical Research Methods, Project Planning and Evaluation.
